messages.subject: Re: EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy, the answer is to create a new bogus ebay account and use that to bid on the sword with. Who cares if he gives you a neg. on an account with little or
messages.messageBody:
Darcy, the answer is to create a new "bogus" ebay account and use
that to bid on the sword with. Who cares if he gives you a neg. on
an account with little or no feedback ?

That is what I did.

- Matt

messages.subject: Re: EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: For those of you with expensive items on your webpages that may be subject to this type of scam, you may want to watermark your pictures, so the potentiall
messages.messageBody:
For those of you with expensive items on your webpages that
may be subject to this type of scam, you may want to
"watermark" your pictures, so the potentiall buyers can tell
what seller or site they are really from.

For an example see my top graphic of my opening page
(right at the bottom of the graphic).

http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

This type of "watermark" is easily done by using the
"shadow" option on the script writer of any word
processor, just a matter of selecting the proper two
colors to be barely visible based on the color background
of your picture.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: ... Remember that a fraudulent seller if on the way out has no problem at all and nothing to lose with dinging you a negative. Even if it is not legit, most
messages.messageBody:
<condell@...> writes:

> I love it. If eBay doesn't respond I can outbid you all near the end
> of the sale and either: 1. Retract my bid explaining the fraud causing
> the house of cards to come tumbling down. 2. "Win" the auction, get
> wire funds transfer from the "seller", and report him to the
> authorities.

> Ideas?

Remember that a fraudulent seller if on the way out has no problem at
all and nothing to lose with dinging you a negative.

Even if it is not legit, most people do not look deep enough for it to
register.

I have three negatives on my account, two from people who tried to scam
me on the buying side, and one because I left a neutral on a seller who
overclaimed the item he was selling. I got negatived for my honesty.

Anyway, the point is that it is not worth it to put yourself into a
position to have someone put a negative comment on your feedback.

Whomever wins should act sincerely. Petitioning ebay to get a bad
feedback item removed is a pain in the rear.

The auction will be promptly taken down if reported via the link I
sent. I have had someone take pictures of a ring I made and put it up on
ebay for $13,000.00 and it was taken down after 24 hours.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: I love it. If eBay doesn t respond I can outbid you all near the end of the sale and either: 1. Retract my bid explaining the fraud causing the house of cards
messages.messageBody:
I love it.
If eBay doesn't respond I can outbid you all
near the end of the sale and either:
1. Retract my bid explaining the fraud causing
the house of cards to come tumbling down.
2. "Win" the auction, get wire funds transfer
from the "seller", and report him to the authorities.

Ideas?

Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: Gentleman, why not put in a fake bid for $20.000 and let the auction end. That way you will find out who the fraudster is when he sends you his bank info for
messages.messageBody:
Gentleman, why not put in a fake bid for $20.000 and let the auction
end. That way you will find out who the fraudster is when he sends you
his bank info for payment. (he will not have registered with ebay unders
his real name) Then report him to ebay and the local authorities in
Thailand ! I did this to some dude in Indonesia a while back with one of
Alf Tan's swords, then sent Alf the info on the dude. I think he must be
in some serious trouble now......................

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: samurai@... [mailto:samurai@...]
Verzonden: donderdag 31 juli 2003 2:17
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
CC: condell@...
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] EBAY FRAUD



Start here:

http://pages.ebay.com/help/index_popup.html?policies=replica-counterfeit
.html

Go to the "Report" link at the bottom of the page.

Only the current "owner" can report it (if this is in the sold gallery,
you may be out of luck unless you want to fudge it a bit).

The above link is worthwhile to be on people's bookmarks. I often use it
to report fake swords, though that apparently does no good.

Going through there usually gets the sale removed in 24 hours.

You cannot email ebay staff.

- darcy

messages.subject: EBAY FRAUD
messages.msgSnippet: I have been informed that one of my gallery items has been fraudulently lifted from my website and is being offered on eBay. Item # 2548766208. See here:
messages.messageBody:
I have been informed that one of my gallery items has been
fraudulently lifted from my website and is being offered on eBay.
Item # 2548766208.

See here:
http://ikkyudo.com/gallery/cat/wak9.htm.

I have contacted eBay and have not heard back.
If anyone knows a shortcut to have this fraudulent sale terminated
please contact me.

--
Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com
